She was examined by a doctor, who found injuries in the genital area, suggestive of force. She sickened, and died of pneumonia in October 1880. At trial, Fuller argued that the father lost no services, and thus had no claim. 131 Mass. 574 (1881).

Cora "was a smart, active girl, bright, cheerful and healthy," when she moved in. Mr. Fuller took "indecent familiarities" with her. Cora became ill with headaches, complained of pain in the "bowels and loins," and her gait was unnatural.

As it was the same to the father -- his injury didn't depend on consent --  the same tort and principles apply to rape as to elopement, seduction cases can be heartbreaking. Hatch v. Fuller is. Cora Hatch was hired at 12 as a "companion" to George Fuller's daughter.

"Seduction" was a claim available to the father of a minor child who was "lured away," or "debauched" causing him to lose her services. In Mass, no such claim was available to the child, even through a next friend. Exotic, old-timey, yet somehow familiar. https://t.co/11lbqCgQah
The father could also sue for the child's pain and suffering, but only as 'next friend' of the child. Anything the father recovered on his own cause of action was his very own, for keepsies.

To provide compensation to the true victim (the father) for injury to a non-working child, courts permitted the father to recover for his own cost, expenses, and inconvenience. Dennis v. Clark, 56 Mass. 347 (1848).

Courts struggled to conceptualize tort recovery for injuries to children too young to work. Obviously, the father was the real victim, but how? (Seen below, child illustrating poor technique as a barber. Clearly not earning his keep). More #legalhistory once I've worked. Maybe. https://t.co/XImgkCy8CF

David Benson abandoned his family (leaving them in extreme poverty) in 1795-ish. The Remingtons took in his daughter, Phoebe. In 1801, when Phoebe was 13, Dave came back and demanded Phoebe and "back wages," from the Remingtons. Dave won. 2 Mass. 113 (1806)

In 1890, the Mass. SJC (a bit incredulously) acknowledged that a husband "can no longer compel [his wife] to work for him during such time as she may choose to perform labor on her sole and separate account."

There was much fretting about how disruptive this all might be. Rather than staying at home, mending pants, boiling diapers and potatoes, and gazing necklessly at their husbands, what if women smoked, drank, and had an androgynous good time? (Both options depicted below). https://t.co/6bvYHOCzoJ

Bit-by-bit, legislation permitted married women to work, earn wages, and own property. In 1879 the SJC first considered whether the term "person" in a statute included "married women," responding, "yes, but maybe just this once."  Snow v. Sheldon, 126 Mass. 332, 335 (1879)

"Married" was the presumed state of adult women during this period. It was frequently held that a man was on notice that a woman not his wife was probably someone else's. (Below, a woman's life reaches its apex when she trades her baby for a hat) https://t.co/wm4PDJlKfa

At common law, wives couldn't sue for (most of) their own torts, not only because they weren't legal persons, but because the damage was to the husband. Her labor belonged to him. Her wages did, too. https://t.co/Lp1YVm3txD

Word: Did you happen to open the document from an email?
Me: You piece of shit. 
Word: Blame Outlook.
Me: Will either of you at least tell me the location of the fucking temporary folder where you let me save my work for two days?
Word: Nope.
Outlook: That'd be telling.

Me: What about recover unsaved documents?
Word: You mean, my secret place? 
Me: Don't call it that. 
Word: Let's see. Just a redline from 2018, with a bunch of macros that make me crash, every time.
Me: Can I delete it?
Word: No. It's in use.
Me: How?

Me: Where's what I was working on?
Word: Oo. You really should save as you go.
Me: I did save.
Word: That sounds like more of a you problem.
Me: I did. 
Word: That's what they all say. Where did you save?
Me: I don't know. Desktop?
Word: Nope.
Me: Documents?
Word: You? Never.

Me: Fine.
Word, from behind three spreadsheets, in a whisper: Ha! Can't. Read only, remember? Come up with a new name, bitch. 
[Rename the document, adding to the hoard of crap on my desktop] 
Word: Okay! Closing everything now! Bye!

Me: Why are there 12 documents still open from Friday? 
Word: I asked you if you wanted to save one of them, in a dialogue box the size of a postage stamp, under 9 other windows.
Me: Did I make any changes to that document?
Word: ?
Me: It's read only.
Word: Just in case, tho.

On appeal, the SJC upheld the conviction, because it seemed a proper instruction had been given permitting the jury to disbelieve the confession, if so inclined. The case is Commonwealth v. Cuffee. Charles Cuffee died in prison of pneumonia at 16.
Charles was tried and convicted, despite the fact that he -- who was slim, and frail, because he was a child -- couldn't have committed the crime, or physically moved the body.

Charles was held in a cell, alone, without "friend or counsel," until the "police" decided to start interrogating him around midnight. He panicked and confessed. His statements were inconsistent (because he didn't know how the crime happened, probably).

Thus, already: No such officers, no such right, no such place. (Charles Cuffee was likely taken to the jail in New Bedford, below). The SJC doesn't seem at all troubled by this, despite the fact that the idea of a municipal police force was in 1871, less than 20 years old. https://t.co/tXhEXG1oZC

Note: The New Bedford Police Department was founded in 1876 (earliest photos I could find, below). Pre '76, there were "watchmen" with constable-like powers. Death investigation was not then (and is not now) under municipal control in Mass. And crossing town lines = not ok. https://t.co/VH4RRilEmb

On Dec. 3, 1870 New Bedford Police Officers investigating the death of a wealthy farmer, took Black teen Charles Cuffee (13) from his school in Westport "against his will, and without a warrant," dragged him to New Bedford, and put him in a cell at the "station-house."

Police as investigators of crime is newer than zippers (1851) programming  (1840s) anesthesia (1840s), rubber condoms (1854), chemical leavening (1830-1856), yet the earliest discussion of police interrogation in a reported case in MA familiar in its bland credulity.

The legislation was ultimately titled: “An act more effectually to protect the sepulchres of the dead, and to legalize the study of anatomy in certain cases.” JC Warren was pleased. Eventually, he and some dentist got together and invented anesthesia, or something.

By December, the “special committee” on "protected sepulchres and also anatomy" had generated a 120-page report, recommending legalization of the study of anatomy. For no reason, here's another photo of John Collins Warren: https://t.co/iWcX0BAuya
The governor, Levi Lincoln, Jr suggested that perhaps the legislature might like to consider just such a recommendation, perhaps via committee in a deceptively gentle speech that June.

Translation: "We recognize that you ordered us to provide a report on body-snatching, however, in our reasoned opinion, go pound, and therefore, please accept this report on the decriminalization of anatomy."

The judiciary committee, on careful consideration, declined to study the further protection of the protected sepulchres, and instead submitted a tight nine pages on the decriminalization of anatomy. https://t.co/EinU2eMo08

Instead, the General Court (the weird Massachusetts term for our legislature) ordered the Committee on the Judiciary to study getting even more protective about the protected sepulchres of the protected dead. Probably by increasing penalties for dissection, exhumation, whatever.

In 1829, or so, perhaps because of Scotland (Burke and Hare), all the cool kids in Mass medicine (I.e., John Collins Warren, and his friend, A.L. Pierson, pictured here) started getting worried about, you know, where the bodies were coming from, and sought legalization. https://t.co/0hmYAa3Lze

The act was titled terribly lyrically, as “An act to protect the sepulchres of the dead.” There were, apparently, prosecutions of medical students and doctors under the act between 1815 and 1830, although few records exist.

In 1815, around when Oliver Wendell Holmes accidentally founded Harvard Medical School as an “upstairs medical college” on Tremont Street, Massachusetts made dissection of cadavers for the study of anatomy even more illegal than it was at common law.

@pervocracy But while it's technically still good law, the assumption of a black-and-white "true legal name" has taken over, especially post 9/11. Maybe the clerks won in the end.

@pervocracy The SJC addressed that in the decision. The fact that there's only one procedure (petition) to legally recognize a change doesn't mean that your chosen name (whatever you use and choose) isn't fundamentally yours whether or not you've filed a petition.

So there it is. In 1977, the Massachusetts SJC ruled that your name is what you say it is. Unless you’re a baby, in which case, it’s what your mom says it is. This very long story was inspired by a tweet from @pervocracy,  which I'd quote if I were better at twitter.
The SJC ordered the clerks to shape up and follow the law, and record the names that people supplied to them. Not the names that the clerks felt were proper.

The SJC even brushed off the idea of a “legal name” as something definitive, black-and-white, or externally imposed, as a principle merely “suggested” by case law and irrelevant to the decision at hand.

The SJC pointed out, in fact, that it had long been the case in Massachusetts, even, that if you want to have and use two different names, for different purposes, you were free to do so. Because why not? You do you.

The SJC didn’t agree. In a long opinion, the court went through the history of naming, at common law, and by statute. The court began with the principle that  at common law a person may change his name at will, without resort to legal proceedings, by merely adopting another name

The clerks just put down any name the parents chose on a birth certificate, how would you know which children were legitimate, and which were bastards? If women could just call themselves by any name they liked, how could anyone tell who owned them?
The clerks argued that recording proper legal names (as they interpreted them) was necessary, and their sworn duty, because otherwise, it would be chaos.

When the Secretary of the Commonwealth sued the clerks (for screwing with public records, and the public) the AG’s office took up the fight. In particular, an Assistant Attorney General named Barbara J. Rouse (who would later be Chief Justice of the Superior Court).

In January of 1976, the association of city clerks issued a policy statement staying that, no matter what the AG said, they would record what they considered to be the proper “legal names” on public records.

City clerks -- who hated having been told how to do their job, by someone whose job it was to do just that -- did something so MA it could almost be served in a plastic cup inside a styrofoam cup: They decided to talk shit after it seemed like the other guy had left the bar.
Robert H. Quinn was replaced as AG by Francis X. Bellotti in 1975. Francis X can be seen here, playing racquetball: https://t.co/tIeQlGUffh
The city clerks were not pleased, considering themselves, pretty much, guardians of the sacred public record, and uniquely positioned to know what someone’s legal name was “supposed to be.”
The overall message was: Come on. Clerks, banks, bureaucrats everywhere: You’re not in charge of what someone’s name is or isn’t.

The third opinion said: City Clerks, really, seriously you guys, I meant it the first time. Please record the names that the parents request, on birth certificates, even you think that hyphenated names are weird.

The second opinion said: City Clerks must record, on birth certificates, the name requested by parents. Even if they think parents are trying to get away with something sneaky by breaking from the pattern of bastards = mother’s name, legitimate children = father’s name.
The first opinion said: A woman’s name is what she says it is, even if, for some reason, her bank would like it to be something different. https://t.co/1B1XOWvKvK

In the mid-1970s, then-Mass. Attorney General Robert H. Quinn issued three opinions, each holding, in slightly different ways and slightly different contexts, that a person’s name is the name they chose (unless they’re a baby, in which case, it’s the name their mom chose).

Here is a story of slightly more recent #legalhistory, that I quite like. In 1977, there was a brawl between every city clerk in Massachusetts, and the Massachusetts Attorney General's Office, over whether there is such a thing as a "legal name."

Still unsatisfied, face unpunched, Danny apparently nudged Hayes-y, and stage-whispered “There's Sammy Wonson; he pulled off his boots, threw them away, and put on the cook's boots.” #WonsonvSayward #StoriesfromPickman #LegalHistory
